The High Temperature Accumulator (V-15) operates at +15 deg. F/ 28.4 psig of pressure and serves numerous purposes. The first of these functions is separating the liquid from the gas in the High Temperature Recirculated Suction lines returning from the cooler evaporators. This prevents damage to the High Stage Compressors. The vessel is also used as storage for the liquid ammonia at the temperature and pressure above for circulation out to the cooler evaporators. This circulation is accomplished by two Recirculator Pumps, RP-3 and RP-4. An additional pump RP-5 is used to transfer liquid out to the compressors and the Thermosyphon Vessel. HPL is supplied to the suction inlet of V-15 to replace the ammonia which is lost when  HSS travels back to the High Stage Compressors for recompression. The vapor in this vessel is a result of the liquid flashed in the evaporators and drawn back, along with the flash gas created in cooling the hot ammonia coming from the Booster Compressors.

The V-14Low Temperature Accumulator operates at -28 deg. F/ 1.3" HG of pressure and serves numerous purposes. The first of these functions is separating the liquid from the gas in the Low Temperature Recirculated Suction lines (LTRS) returning from the freezer evaporators. This prevents damage to the Low Stage/Booster Compressors. This vessel is also used as storage for the liquid ammonia at the temperature and pressure above for circulation out to the freezer evaporators and liquid makeup to the V-21 Low Temperature Accumulator. This circulation is accomplished by two Recirculator Pumps, RP-1 and RP-2. HTRL is supplied to the suction inlet of this vessel to provide liquid make up for any ammonia vapor lost to the compressors maintaining temperature. The ammonia vapor is designated Low State Suction (LSS) and travels back to the Low Stage/Booster Compressors.

f pressure and operates in the same manner as the V-14 vessel. Like the V-14 the first function is separating the liquid from the gas in the Low Temperature Recirculated Suction lines (LTRS) returning from the freezer evaporators. This prevents damage to the Low Stage/Booster Compressors. This vessel is also used as storage for the liquid ammonia at the temperature and pressure above for circulation out to the Belt Freezer evaporators. This circulation is accomplished by two Recirculator Pumps, RP-6 and RP-7. Makeup liquid refrigerant is normally supplied via the LTRL line from the V-14 liquid pumps; alternatively MTRL refrigerant can also feed the vessel from the V-15 liquid pumps. The ammonia vapor is designated Low State Suction (LSS) and travels back to the Low Stage/Booster Compressors.

The fourteen Product Cooler Evaporators designated EV-DA, EV-DB up to EV-I, and HX-1 flash off HTRL pumped from the V-15 to provide cooling for the product in storage rooms and the refrigerated glycol. The refrigerated storage rooms are maintained at a temperature of around +34 deg. F. The heat exchanger HX-1 maintains the glycol at 26 deg. F. For proper operation of the evaporators more liquid ammonia is pumped to the coils than what is actually flashed/ boiled off in the cooling process. For these coils the recirculation rate is approximately 3 to 1, three parts liquid ammonia to one part ammonia vapor. This mixture exiting the coils is designated Medium Temperature Re-circulated Suction (HTRS) and is drawn back to V-15.

The eight Product Freezer Evaporators designated EV-AA, EV-AB up to EV-BB, and EV111A up to EV112B flash off LTRL pumped from V-14 to provide cooling for the product in storage. These rooms are maintained at a temperature between -10 and -20 deg. F. These coils also operate at approximately a three to one recirculation rate. The combination of gas and liquid exiting the coils is designated Low Temperature Re-circulated Suction (LTRS) and is drawn back to V-1

Gerber Products Company is proud to inform all interested parties that our company is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM), Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations 1910.119, and EPA's Risk Management Program regulations (RMP), Title 40 CFR Part 68.  In addition to other state and local codes applicable to our facility and process. We have undertaken this process to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling, and use of Anhydrous Ammonia in our facility.

Our goal is to promote overall worker, public, and plant safety.

Gerber Products Company is located at 405 West State Street, Fremont, Michigan. The facility includes processing tanks, piping, packaging equipment, raw materials warehousing, finished goods refrigerated storage, an Ammonia refrigeration engine room, boilers, and miscellaneous utilities.  

The refrigeration system required for our production process necessitates the submission of this Risk Management Plan.  The refrigeration system contains in excess of 18,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  This surpasses the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds outlined in Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program regulations.

Gerber Products Company has implemented numerous policies and procedures to enable our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences of significant releases of Anhydrous Ammonia as well as other hazardous substances, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.  Overall these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid property damage.

Our safety programs prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures, and practices that govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment.  These rules are detailed and improved as necessary.  They are also communicated to and accepted by all employees at our facility.

Gerber Products Company ammonia refrigeration system also incorporates additional safety items such as

tagging of all valves and components, and a PC / PLC based control system with a graphical operator interface that controls mitigating devices such as emergency exhaust fans, emergency shutdown systems and alarms.

Refrigeration Process Description

The process chemistry of the system documented here is relatively simple since no chemical reactions occur in a closed loop mechanical system such as we have here. All processes that occur have to do with changes of state between liquid and vapor phases and their impact on heat transfer. 

This refrigeration plant has a three temperature system for greater operating efficiency, the 1st temperature being +15 deg F, also referred to as high temperature, for general refrigeration, the 2nd temperature being -28 deg F. called low temperature, for the storage freezers and the 3rd temperature being -45 deg F. also called low temperature, for the low temperature Belt Freezer. The High Temperature System, +15 system includes all equipment fed from the High Temperature Accumulator (V-15) which includes the ten Cooler Evaporators, along with the plate and frame heat exchanger. The -28 deg F Low Temperature Systems is fed from the Low Temperature Accumulator (V-14). This vessel provides for the eight Freezer Evaporators. The -45 deg F Low Temperature Systems is fed from the Low Temperature Accumulator (V-21). This vessel provides for the two Belt Freezer Evaporators.

To continue this description we will start at the screw compressors, there are seven total, three compressors are Low Stage or Boosters and four are High Stage.
 
The three Low Stage Compressors (LS-1 - LS-3) draw low pressure gas (LSS) Low Stage Suction from either V-14 or V-21 Low Temperature Accumulators into the compressor where it is compressed by rotating screws. This produces a medium pressure; medium temperature vapor designated Booster Discharge (BD), which flows to V-15, the High Temperature Accumulator for cooling.

The four High Stage Compressors (HS-1 thru

HS-4) draw ammonia vapor from V-15 and compress it using the same process as low stage compressors. This hot high pressure gas which also referred to High Stage Discharge or Hot Gas (HSD, HG) travels to the three Evaporative Condensers.

The Evaporative Condensers, (EC-1 thru EC-3) are where all the heat picked up by the ammonia in the system is removed by the evaporation of water. Once the heat is removed the ammonia vapor condenses inside the condenser coils becoming a high pressure liquid called Condensate Drain (CD), later referred to as HPL. This liquid then flows by gravity to the Thermosyphon Vessel (V-17).

The Thermosyphon Vessel (V-17) serves two purposes; first it serves as a storage vessel for the high pressure liquid ammonia, at +95 deg. F/ 181 psig of pressure. But it primary function is to provide liquid ammonia for the cooling of the compressors. The compressors are cooled by circulating liquid ammonia Thermosyphon Suppy(TSS) down to the compressor oil coolers/heat exchangers, where it flashes/boils off, cooling the oil that has absorbed the heat of compressing the ammonia gas. This HP ammonia vapor, designated Thermosyphon Return (TSR), from the oil coolers then circulates by natural convection back up to the this Vessel and the process is repeated. CD/ ammonia stored in the Thermosyphon Vessel also flows through one line to the Vertical Receiver (V-16), which is discussed shortly. V-17 is connected by an equalization line to the HSD from the compressors to the evaporative condensers. This allows pressures to/from both sides of the evaporative condensers to balance, allowing liquid to freely flow down from them to the vessel.

V-16, the Vertical Receiver stores CD from the Thermosyphon Vessel. The Vertical Receiver is the main storage site for liquid ammonia used in the plant. Liquid ammonia is stored at +95 deg. F/ 181 psig of pressure and is designated as High Pressure Liquid, (HPL). From this vessel the ammonia is transferred to the High Tempera

The two Belt Freezer Evaporators designated EV-BF1A and BF1B flash off LTRL pumped from V-14 to provide cooling for the product in storage. These rooms are maintained at a temperature between -10 and -20 deg. F. These coils also operate at approximately a three to one recirculation rate. Additionally these coils are attached to an overd suction header or "leg"; this header is fitted with a liquid pump. The liquid pump recirculates overfeed liquid from the suction of each coil back to the coils liquid supply line. The header is also fitted with a level probe; this probe maintains a liquid level via the LTRL line, and pumps excess refrigerant back to the V21 recirculator. The gas exiting the header is combined with any liquid returned via the liquid pump and is designated Low Temperature Re-circulated Suction (LTRS) and is drawn back to V-21.

Heat Exchanger (V-13) takes waste heat from the system and uses it to heat a glycol, water mix which is circulated to transfer heat to under-floor piping in the freezers to prevent the ground from freezing under the concrete floor and causing damage.

The Anhydrator (V-20) is a small vessel that removes water and other impurities from the ammonia in the refrigeration system. This is achieved by taking waste heat from the HG/HSD from the compressors and boiling off liquid ammonia at a very low temperature by using the suction provided by the Low Temperature Accumulator (V-14).

Oil Pots, (V-18 and V-19) are small vessels that receive refrigerant oil circulating in the system and isolate it for transfer and removal from the system.

Additional Features: Pump Out (PO), this circuit allows for rapid removal of liquid ammonia and oil from all major pieces of equipment in this system. The Pump Out lines terminate at the Low Temperature Accumulator (V-14). 


Summary of The Five-Year Accident History

Gerber Products Company has had no reportable accidents in the last five years involving ammonia.

Description of the Emergency Resp

onse Plan

Purpose: 	
This Procedure is written to help ensure the safety and protection of our employees, responders, neighbors and environment in the event of a chemical release emergency.  In addition this procedure provides a structured response to mitigating the emergency and ensures compliance with both Occupational Health & Safety and Environmental Protection regulations.

Scope:
This procedure applies to all activities at the Gerber Products Company Fremont Site, and includes releases of hazardous or polluting materials.  Those materials include but are not limited to; anhydrous ammonia, caustic & acid based cleaners, petroleum and vegetable oils, paints and paint solvents, pesticides, water treatment chemicals, process chemicals, cleaners containing sodium hypochlorite, hydrogen peroxide and hazardous wastes.
This procedure does not apply to incidental spills or releases that may be mitigated by operators or supervision.

Responsibility:
Annual review and subsequent updates to this plan are the responsibility of the Fremont factory Safety, Health and Environment Manager.
It is the responsibility of the emergency response team (ERT) to respond and mitigate all chemical release emergencies resulting from activities or uses of chemicals at the Fremont site.

Procedure: 

Pre-emergency planning
Chemical emergency response training is provided to each member of the emergency response team (ERT).  Hazardous material technician level (24 hour) training is provided to those team members who will be directly involved in mitigation, clean up or decontamination activities.  Trainers and training materials shall meet State requirements for technician level.  Annual refresher training and periodic practice drills are provided to keep ERT skills curren

t. 

Local Emergency response and health care organizations are included in the practice drills.  Inspections of chemical storage areas and process systems are offered annually to the local fire department.

Personnel Roles
In the event of a chemical release the Gerber ERT will be dispatched to assess, mitigate and clean up the release.  The incident command system will be put into place.  Members of the ERT have completed IC training.  Should additional resources be needed the ERT will request site security to call 911 for assistance from local fire departments and/or medical services.
The site Gerber Emergency Management Team will assume an additional support and management role.  This role will include resource allocation, logistics, data, documentation, and communications both internal and external.

Recognition and Prevention
Employees are trained to recognize a chemical emergency during their job orientation and hazard communication training.  Employees and supervisors are instructed to call for the ERT if a release cannot be contained without potential exposure.  Between Gerber employees and site security, chemical process systems and chemical storage are monitored around the clock seven days a week (24/7).  Preventative maintenance is performed on the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system.  The site has a Risk Management Plan and a Process Safety Management Plan for the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system.

Safe distances and places of refuge
In the event of a chemical release inside a building, which has the potential to create an unsafe atmosphere, the refrigeration building will be evacuated.  In the event that the chemical release would not pose an inhalation hazard, the area of the spill and an appropriate buffer zone will be evacuated until the spill can be cleaned up. Should a site wide chemical emergency occur, the maintenance departments will shut down air handling systems as needed.  In the event of an exterior exposure the employees will be di

rected to the unexposed side of the building for sheltering in place in the event of an exterior exposure or a full evacuation if the exposure is interior.
Air monitoring, wind direction and release rates shall determine safe distances and locations.

Site security and control
The Fremont Campus is monitored 24/7 by a contracted security firm.  During a chemical emergency security shall be used to ensure that effected areas are kept clear of unauthorized individuals. Supplemental security may also be provided by supervisors and ERT.  Access to an emergency scene is limited to members of the ERT and local emergency resources that may have been requested.

Evacuation routes and procedures
Evacuation routes are posted for sheltering in place and evacuation from buildings.  Supervisors are responsible for assisting in the evacuation and determining that all employees are accounted for. 
Processes that could pose further danger if left unattended will be shut down according to emergency shut down procedures prior to operators evacuating (if the procedure can be performed without risk of exposure to the operator).  Evacuation drills are practiced annually and evacuation routes are reviewed for effectiveness.  
Safe areas will always be upwind of the release.

Decontamination 
Decontamination of people, property and personal protective equipment is the responsibility of the ERT and is performed after a chemical release clean up. Decontamination water is neutralized or contained and treated as hazardous waste in accordance with hazardous waste regulations.  Decontamination is performed by Gerber employees trained in decontamination procedures with assistance from the local fire department as needed.  Decontamination occurs as people and property leave the contaminated area and after the clean up is complete. 

Medical Treatment and First Aid
Any Gerber Products Co. employee who is exposed to inhalation chemical levels will be sent for medical evaluation and treatment.  Any

Gerber Products Co. employee who physically contacts chemicals will be decontaminated and treated as needed.  First aid is available on site from trained individuals.  If any further treatment is needed, individuals will be sent to Gerber Memorial Hospital.  

Emergency alerting and response procedure
Employees working in an area with a chemical spill or release are instructed to notify site security by calling the internal emergency number 62233.  Witnessing a release may include hearing an alarm from a sensing monitor.
Upon being notified security will utilize the public address system to dispatch the emergency response team, and to notify employees on the type of emergency and provide further instructions. 
Should a chemical release have the potential to migrate off Gerber property individuals in the community adjacent to the property will be alerted.  Relevant data will be supplied to the police department by the site HSEO or his designee.  The police department will then have the task of notifying the effected community.

Critique of response and follow up
As soon as possible following a response to a chemical release a team will convene to critique the response.  The team will be composed of members of management, ERT and the affected operations.  The purpose of the critique is to gather data for performance improvement should another event occur.  In addition the root cause or causes of the release will be investigated to provide corrective measures to prevent future releases.

PPE and emergency equipment
Emergency equipment for response to chemical releases is stored in a controlled area and is inspected at least monthly and after each use.  Equipment is removed from service should anything be found during an inspection that could negatively effect the use of the equipment.  Removing equipment from service includes attaching a red tag with the date, name of person tagging equipment and the reason for removing the equipment from service. The HSE department ke

eps records of inspections and servicing.
Responders are fit tested for self-contained breathing apparatus annually and are included in the respiratory protection program for tight fitting respirators.  The responders are trained in the use and limitations of their equipment and PPE.  The Organizational Development department maintains training records.

Conclusion

Gerber Products Company is committed to continuous improvement of our policies, procedures, and facility. It is the intention of Gerber Products Company to remain an industry leader. New technology, training techniques, and equipment are continuously being added to our system to insure the safety of the personnel, environment, and the product.
